text: Family Member: Yeah, uh hum. Doctor: We know a lot about the side effects. Family Member: Well with having chemotherapy, would that be, I know it’s not the same drug, but the same effect like I had chemotherapy for breast cancer? Doctor: Yes, we use one drug. We use Taxotere. So I don’t which ones you got. Family Member: I had Adriamycin and Cytoxan. Doctor: Yeah, it’s a little bit different. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: We think it’s probably a little bit better tolerated because we’re only giving one drug Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: than it is you know the hair loss, the nausea, the vomiting, Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: you know the numbness of the fingertips, excess tearing, you know changes in blood counts, that you’re at risk for infection, can cause liver injury, nausea, things that you feel

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: And, uh- (Sound Door opens) Patient: Right. Doctor: And within the apricot seeds, there’s a compound that can be converted. The downfall of the idea, so, scientifically, was actually kind of an interesting idea. But the downfall is humans don’t have the enzyme to convert the thing to cyanide. So it was never going to work because we just don’t have the enzyme. So it, so they did a lot of things, and patients went to Mexico, and they did this. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Uh, and it didn’t really have any success. What your, you’re showing me something else. I don’t know anything about vitamin B-seventeen. I didn’t know there was a B-seventeen. Patient: Yes. I know. No, nobody knows. Doctor: And so whether that’s anything that, I, I don’t know anything about that, so I can’t really tell you- Patient: Yeah. I know you don’t know about vitamins. Doctor: But that’s what the apricot seed was. Now I don’t know if they got a bunch of apricot seed ground up later on, and going, hey, we’ve got to get rid of this. Let’s go with a different story. Doctor: Uh, that would be one of my worries with all this kind of stuff. Patient: Yeah. Right. Doctor: So whenever I hear we’re going to go down to Mexico-

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: Because you have to be positive to go onto that study. The other two studies, it doesn’t matter about what your AR-V7. AR-V7 gives us a sense of what’s the likelihood that Enzalutamide’s gonna work. Patient: Okay. Doctor: What’s the likelihood that Abiraterone’s gonna work. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Um. In this case, we’re trying to just sort out men who, um, have an AR-V7 positive as a bad thing. Uh. So, that says that we’re willing to go with immune therapy which hasn’t been proven at a high risk/high gain, uh, thing in that kind of individual. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh. (pause) Patient: Right. Doctor: That it’s clear that this isn’t helping you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, we could say, “No, let’s move on.” I can give you the, uh, consent forms. But, if you already know, that I don’t want to do chemotherapy, I know I’m not going to come in here. The consent form does explain chemotherapy. So, that’s something that you’d be entertaining as a next step, whether it be here or locally.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: But if something's obviously seen on an additional scan, you know, we have clinical studies that we could think about. Patient: Right. Doctor: So we have one study where folks you know less than three spots. And as long as one is in bone, we radiate pinpoint radiation, the spots that we see- Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: -and half the people get of medicine that goes in their bloodstream that goes to cancer in the bone. Patient: Right. Doctor: And so that would be something that you know, based on sort of, if we really think T12 is real or T3 is real, that could be something that we would send you off to the radiation doctors to have them talk about that trial. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Then we get the PET scan and it actually says, you know, you've got 123 plus 456, you know, that we think most of this is real, we can step back and watch a little bit longer until either declares itself a little bit more. Patient: Right. Doctor: Or just say hey, it's there. And then we have a couple studies where the current standard for the guy who shows up with multiple spots is to go on hormones for life. Patient: Right.

See that’s why I lost a lot of weight because of that. Doctor: Alright so I can make one change at a time. Which one do you want to go? text: Patient: Yeah, I didn’t imagine, no idea. Doctor: Yeah. No. I agree. Yeah. So I think you should consider going on the study because that is our only chance, at least in the U.S., of getting on the medication. If you don’t, we are no better off than what we started with. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But now is a good time to consider the study because your cancer is not going crazy. Okay? Family Member: Right. Doctor: You know? It’s only the PSA is inching up, but nothing else is getting worse. Patient: So I’ll only be in Texas for now long? Doctor: One or two days. Patient: A couple of days? Doctor: Yeah. text: Patient: Right. Doctor: But that’s something may not be so as aggressive or as detrimental on your quality of life as the hormone therapy, for example, which has all these systemic side effects. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So I wasn’t necessarily seeing it as hormones plus radiation at the same time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I was seeing it as doing the radiation therapy as a way to sort of avoid or push back the need for the hormones. Family Member: Because the radiation is just going to target that one area. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Correct. Family Member: And the cancer still. Healthcare Professional: But the thing is, too, you’ll also be observed. You know so you’ll still be getting PSA levels done. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
